<!--
NOTE:
This article is about comparisons between stories, artistic depictions, and religious elements of Jesus's life and those of mythical or legendary figures from the ancient Mediterranean, including figures from Jewish mythology, made by reputable, mainstream, contemporary scholars of the ancient world, including historians of early Christianity. It is NOT about fringe theories advanced by popular writers and people on the internet, or arguments that Jesus was not a real person; those are dealt with in the article Christ myth theory. Thank you.
---> {{multiple image|perrow = 2|total_width=300 | image1 = Cefalù Pantocrator retouched.jpg|width1=1200|height1= | image2 = Bacchus and Silenus BM 1899.2-15.1 n01.jpg|width2=1200|height2= | image3 = Fresque Mithraeum Marino.jpg|width3=1200|height3= | image4 = Disc Sol BM GR1899.12-1.2.jpg|width4=1200|height4= | image5 = BD Hunefer cropped 2.jpg|width5=1200|height5= | image6 = Asclepius and hygieia relief.jpg|width6=|height6=1600 | image7 = Bust Attis CdM.jpg|width7=|height7=1600 | image8 = Aphrodite Adonis Louvre MNB2109.jpg|width8=1200|height8= | footer = Jesus has been compared to a broad variety of figures from various mythological traditions within the [[Mediterranean Basin]], including (in rows from left to right) [[Dionysus]], [[Mithraism|Mithras]], [[Sol Invictus]], [[Osiris]], [[Asclepius]], [[Attis]], and [[Adonis]] }} The study of '''Jesus in comparative mythology''' is the examination of the narratives of the life of [[Jesus]] in the [[Canonical gospel|Christian gospel]]s, [[Christian traditions|traditions]] and [[theology]], as they relate to [[Christianity]] and other religions. Although virtually all [[New Testament]] scholars and historians of the [[ancient Near East]] agree that [[Historicity of Jesus|Jesus existed as a historical figure]],<ref name=Blomberg>{{cite book|last=Blomberg|first=Craig L.|title=The Historical Reliability of the Gospels|year=2007|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=9780830828074}}</ref><ref name=Carrier>{{cite book|last=Carrier|first=Richard Lane|title=On the Historicity of Jesus: Why We Might Have Reason for Doubt|year=2014|publisher=Sheffield Phoenix Press|isbn=9781909697355}}</ref><ref name=fox>{{cite book|last=Fox|first=Robin Lane|title=The Classical World: An Epic History from Homer to Hadrian|year=2005|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0465024971|page=48}}</ref><ref name=nobbs>{{cite web|last1=Dickson|first1=John|title=Best of 2012: The irreligious assault on the historicity of Jesus|url=http://www.abc.net.au/religion/articles/2012/12/24/3660194.htm|website=Abc.net.au|accessdate=17 June 2014}}</ref>{{refn|group=nb|While discussing the "striking" fact that "we don't have any Roman records, of any kind, that attest to the existence of Jesus," Ehrman dismisses claims that this means Jesus never existed, saying, "He certainly existed, as virtually every competent scholar of antiquity, Christian or non-Christian, agrees, based on clear and certain evidence."<ref name="Ehrman2011">{{cite book|author=Bart D. Ehrman|title=Forged: Writing in the Name of God--Why the Bible's Authors Are Not Who We Think They Are|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MtOMO8i4GLoC|date=22 March 2011|publisher=HarperCollins|pages= 285|isbn=978-0-06-207863-6}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=nb|[[Robert M. Price]], a former fundamentalist apologist turned atheist who says the existence of Jesus cannot be ruled out, but is less probable than non-existence, agrees that his perspective runs against the views of the majority of scholars.<ref name="Dunn2010">{{cite book|author=James Douglas Grant Dunn|title=The Historical Jesus: Five Views|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DtRhzgAACAAJ|date=1 February 2010|publisher=[[SPCK Publishing]] |pages= 61|isbn=978-0-281-06329-1}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=nb|[[Michael Grant (author)|Michael Grant]] (a [[classicist]]) states that "In recent years, 'no serious scholar has ventured to postulate the non historicity of Jesus, or at any rate very few, and they have not succeeded in disposing of the much stronger, indeed very abundant, evidence to the contrary."<ref name="Grant2004">{{cite book|author=Michael Grant|title=Jesus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zVUxICZlgYIC|date=January 2004|publisher=Orion|pages= 200|isbn=978-1-898799-88-7}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=nb|"There are those who argue that Jesus is a figment of the Church’s imagination, that there never was a Jesus at all. I have to say that I do not know any respectable critical scholar who says that any more."<ref name="BurridgeGould2004">{{cite book|author1=Richard A. Burridge|author2=Graham Gould|title=Jesus Now and Then|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AB3ciLwoWkQC|year=2004|publisher=William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company|pages= 34|isbn=978-0-8028-0977-3}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=nb|[[Maurice Casey]], an irreligious Emeritus Professor of New Testament Languages and Literature at the [[University of Nottingham]], concludes in his book ''Jesus: Evidence and Argument or Mythicist Myths?'' that "the whole idea that Jesus of Nazareth did not exist as a historical figure is verifiably false. Moreover, it has not been produced by anyone or anything with any reasonable relationship to critical scholarship. It belongs to the fantasy lives of people who used to be fundamentalist Christians. They did not believe in critical scholarship then, and they do not do so now. I cannot find any evidence that any of them have adequate professional qualifications."{{sfn|Casey|2014|page=243}}}} most secular historians also agree that the gospels contain large quantities of ahistorical [[legend]]ary details mixed in with historical information about Jesus's life.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=184–185}} The [[Synoptic Gospels]] of [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]], [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]], and [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]] are heavily shaped by Jewish tradition, with the Gospel of Matthew deliberately portraying Jesus as a "new [[Moses]]".{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=198–199}} Although it is highly unlikely that the authors of the Synoptic Gospels directly based any of their stories on pagan mythology,{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=53–54}} it is possible that they may have subtly shaped their accounts of [[Miracles of Jesus#Cures|Jesus's healing miracles]] to resemble familiar Greek stories about miracles associated with [[Asclepius]], the god of healing and medicine.{{sfn|Edelstein|Edelstein|1998|pages=133–134}}{{sfn|Hill|2004|pages=67–68}} The [[Nativity of Jesus|birth narratives]] of Matthew and Luke are usually seen by secular historians as legends designed to fulfill Jewish expectations about the Messiah.{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pp=85–88}}
The [[Gospel of John]] bears indirect influences from [[Platonism]], via earlier Jewish deuterocanonical texts, and may also have been influenced in less obvious ways by the cult of [[Dionysus]], the Greek god of wine, though this possibility is still disputed.{{sfn|Salier|2004|pages=66–69}} Later [[Jesus in Christianity|Christian traditions about Jesus]] were probably influenced by [[Religion in ancient Rome|Greco-Roman religion]] and [[Classical mythology|mythology]]. Much of [[Depiction of Jesus|Jesus's traditional iconography]] is apparently derived from Mediterranean deities such as [[Hermes]], Asclepius, [[Serapis]], and [[Zeus]] and his [[Christmas|traditional birthdate on 25 December]], which was not declared as such until the fifth century, was at one point named a holiday in honor of the Roman sun god [[Sol Invictus]]. At around the same time Christianity was expanding in the second and third centuries, the [[Mithraism|Mithraic Cult]] was also flourishing. Though the relationship between the two religions is still under dispute, [[Christian apologetics|Christian apologists]] at the time noted similarities between them, which some scholars have taken as evidence of borrowing, but which are more likely a result of shared cultural environment. More general comparisons have also been made between the stories about Jesus's birth and resurrection and stories of other divine or heroic figures from across the Mediterranean world, including supposed "[[Dying-and-rising deity|dying-and-rising gods]]" such as [[Dumuzid|Tammuz]], [[Adonis]], [[Attis]], and [[Osiris]], while the concept of "dying-and-rising gods" has received criticism.
==Legendary material in the gospels== ===Synoptic gospels=== [[File:Bloch-SermonOnTheMount.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|right|The [[Sermon on the Mount]] from the [[Gospel of Matthew]], depicted in this nineteenth-century painting by [[Carl Bloch]], is an example of an instance in which one of the gospel-writers shapes his account in light of Jewish tradition.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=199}}{{sfn|Sanders|1993|page=146}} Although the contents of the sermon are mostly authentic sayings of the historical Jesus,{{sfn|Theissen|Merz|1998|pages=17–62}} the context of the sermon is a literary invention to make Jesus seem like a "new [[Moses]]".{{sfn|Theissen|Merz|1998|pages=17–62}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=199}}]]
{{main|Jesus|Historicity of Jesus|Historical Jesus}}
Virtually all [[New Testament]] scholars and historians of the [[ancient Near East]], applying the standard criteria of historical investigation, agree that [[Historicity of Jesus|Jesus existed as a historical figure]].<ref name=Blomberg>{{cite book|last=Blomberg|first=Craig L.|title=The Historical Reliability of the Gospels|year=2007|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=9780830828074}}</ref><ref name=Carrier>{{cite book|last=Carrier|first=Richard Lane|title=On the Historicity of Jesus: Why We Might Have Reason for Doubt|year=2014|publisher=Sheffield Phoenix Press|isbn=9781909697355}}</ref><ref name=fox>{{cite book|last=Fox|first=Robin Lane|title=The Classical World: An Epic History from Homer to Hadrian|year=2005|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0465024971|page=48}}</ref><ref name=nobbs>{{cite web|last1=Dickson|first1=John|title=Best of 2012: The irreligious assault on the historicity of Jesus|url=http://www.abc.net.au/religion/articles/2012/12/24/3660194.htm|website=Abc.net.au|accessdate=17 June 2014}}</ref>{{refn|group=nb|While discussing the "striking" fact that "we don't have any Roman records, of any kind, that attest to the existence of Jesus," Ehrman dismisses claims that this means Jesus never existed, saying, "He certainly existed, as virtually every competent scholar of antiquity, Christian or non-Christian, agrees, based on clear and certain evidence."<ref name="Ehrman2011">{{cite book|author=Bart D. Ehrman|title=Forged: Writing in the Name of God--Why the Bible's Authors Are Not Who We Think They Are|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MtOMO8i4GLoC|date=22 March 2011|publisher=HarperCollins|pages= 285|isbn=978-0-06-207863-6}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=nb|[[Robert M. Price]], a former fundamentalist apologist turned atheist who says the existence of Jesus cannot be ruled out, but is less probable than non-existence, agrees that his perspective runs against the views of the majority of scholars.<ref name="Dunn2010">{{cite book|author=James Douglas Grant Dunn|title=The Historical Jesus: Five Views|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DtRhzgAACAAJ|date=1 February 2010|publisher=[[SPCK Publishing]] |pages= 61|isbn=978-0-281-06329-1}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=nb|[[Michael Grant (author)|Michael Grant]] (a [[classicist]]) states that "In recent years, 'no serious scholar has ventured to postulate the non historicity of Jesus, or at any rate very few, and they have not succeeded in disposing of the much stronger, indeed very abundant, evidence to the contrary."<ref name="Grant2004">{{cite book|author=Michael Grant|title=Jesus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zVUxICZlgYIC|date=January 2004|publisher=Orion|pages= 200|isbn=978-1-898799-88-7}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=nb|"There are those who argue that Jesus is a figment of the Church’s imagination, that there never was a Jesus at all. I have to say that I do not know any respectable critical scholar who says that any more."<ref name="BurridgeGould2004">{{cite book|author1=Richard A. Burridge|author2=Graham Gould|title=Jesus Now and Then|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AB3ciLwoWkQC|year=2004|publisher=William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company|pages= 34|isbn=978-0-8028-0977-3}}</ref>}} While some scholars have criticized Jesus scholarship for religious bias and lack of [[Historical method|methodological soundness]],{{refn|group=nb|"...The point I shall argue below is that, the agreed evidentiary practices of the historians of Yeshua, despite their best efforts, have not been those of sound historical practice".<ref name="Akenson2001">{{cite book|author=Donald H. Akenson|title=Surpassing Wonder: The Invention of the Bible and the Talmuds|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=40E8am9SlwgC|date=29 September 2001|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-01073-1}}</ref>}} with very few exceptions such critics generally do support the historicity of Jesus and reject the [[Christ myth theory]] that Jesus never existed.{{sfn|Van Voorst|2000|page=16}}{{refn|group=nb|"[F]arfetched theories that Jesus' existence was a Christian invention are highly implausible."<ref name="Bockmuehl2001">{{cite book|author=Markus Bockmuehl|title=The Cambridge Companion to Jesus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vSehrtQpcYcC|date=8 November 2001|publisher=Cambridge University Press|pages =123–124|isbn=978-0-521-79678-1}}</ref>}}<ref name="Powell1998">{{cite book|author=Mark Allan Powell|title=Jesus as a Figure in History: How Modern Historians View the Man from Galilee|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IJP4DRCVaUMC|year=1998|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|pages= 168|isbn=978-0-664-25703-3}}</ref><ref name="Houlden2003">{{cite book|author=James L. Houlden|title=Jesus in History, Thought, and Culture: Entries A - J.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GjvmQgAACAAJ|year=2003|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-856-3}}</ref><ref name=VVoorst14>{{cite book|author=Robert E. Van Voorst|title=Jesus Outside the New Testament: An Introduction to the Ancient Evidence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lwzliMSRGGkC|year=2000|pages= 14|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0-8028-4368-5}}</ref> There is widespread disagreement among scholars about the accuracy of details of Jesus's life as it is described in the gospel narratives, and on the meaning of his teachings,{{refn|group=nb|Of "baptism and crucifixion", these "two facts in the life of Jesus command almost universal assent".<ref name="Dunn2003a">{{cite book|author=James D. G. Dunn|title=Jesus Remembered|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G4qpnvoautgC|year=2003|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|pages= 339|isbn=978-0-8028-3931-2}}</ref>}}<ref name=Hertzog1/>{{refn|group=nb|"That he was crucified is as sure as anything historical can ever be, since both Josephus and Tacitus ... agree with the Christian accounts on at least that basic fact."<ref name="Crossan1994">{{cite book|author=John Dominic Crossan|title=Jesus: A Revolutionary Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R76BnTswxEsC|year=1994|publisher=HarperCollins|pages= 45|isbn=978-0-06-061662-5}}</ref>}}<ref name="MAPowell168">{{cite book|author=Mark Allan Powell|title=Jesus as a Figure in History: How Modern Historians View the Man from Galilee|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IJP4DRCVaUMC|year=1998|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|isbn=978-0-664-25703-3}}</ref>{{rp|168–173}}<ref name=MAPowell168 /> and the only two events subject to "almost universal assent" are that [[Baptism of Jesus|Jesus was baptized]] by [[John the Baptist]] and that [[Crucifixion of Jesus|he was crucified]] under the orders of the Roman prefect [[Pontius Pilate]].<ref name=Hertzog1>William A. Herzog. ''Prophet and Teacher: An Introduction to the Historical Jesus'' (4 Jul 2005) {{ISBN|0664225284}} pp. 1–6</ref><ref name="MAPowell168" /><ref name=JDunn339>''Jesus Remembered'' by James D. G. Dunn 2003 {{ISBN|0-8028-3931-2}} p. 339 states of baptism and crucifixion that these "two facts in the life of Jesus command almost universal assent".</ref><ref name="autogenerated145" >{{cite book |author=Crossan, John Dominic |title=Jesus: A Revolutionary Biography |isbn=0-06-061662-8 |year=1995 |publisher=HarperOne |quote=That he was crucified is as sure as anything historical can ever be, since both Josephus and Tacitus ... agree with the Christian accounts on at least that basic fact. |page=145}}</ref><ref name=AmyJill4>{{cite book|author1=Amy-Jill Levine|author2=Dale C. Allison Jr.|author3=John Dominic Crossan|title=The Historical Jesus in Context|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wMbEyeDSQQgC|date=16 October 2006|publisher=Princeton University Press|pages= 4|isbn=0-691-00992-9}}</ref> It is also generally, although not universally, accepted that Jesus was a Galilean Jew who [[First disciples of Jesus|called disciples]] and whose activities were confined to Galilee and Judea, that he had a [[Cleansing of the Temple|controversy in the Temple]], and that, after his crucifixion, his ministry was continued by a group of his disciples, several of whom were persecuted.{{sfn|Herzog|2005|pages=1–6}}{{sfn|Chilton|Evans|2002|pages=3–7}}
Nonetheless, most secular scholars generally agree that the gospels contain large amounts of material that is not historically accurate and is better categorized as legend.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=184–185}} In a discussion of genuinely legendary episodes from the gospels, theologian [[Bart Ehrman]] mentions the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth narratives in the Gospels of Matthew and Luke]] and the release of [[Barabbas]].{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=184}} He points out, however, that, just because these stories are not true does not mean that Jesus himself did not exist.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=184–185}} According to theologians Paul R. Eddy and [[Gregory A. Boyd]], there is no evidence that the portrayal of Jesus in the [[Synoptic Gospels]] (the three earliest gospels of [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]], [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]], and [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]]) was directly influenced by pagan mythology in any significant way.{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=53–54}}<ref name=Collins>[[Gerald O'Collins]], "The Hidden Story of Jesus" ''New Blackfriars'' Volume 89, Issue 1024, pages 710–714, November 2008</ref> The earliest followers of Jesus were devout Palestinian Jews who abhorred paganism{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=98–99}} and would have therefore been extremely unlikely to model stories about their founder on pagan myths.{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=53–54}}
Despite this, several scholars have noticed that some of the [[Miracles of Jesus#Cures|healing miracles of Jesus]] recorded in the Synoptic Gospels bear similarities to Greek stories of miracles associated with [[Asclepius]], the god of healing and medicine.{{sfn|Edelstein|Edelstein|1998|pages=133–134}}{{sfn|Hill|2004|pages=67–68}}{{sfn|Cotter|2010|page=73}} Brennan R. Hill states that Jesus's miracles are, for the most part, clearly told in the context of the Jewish belief in the healing power of Yahweh,{{sfn|Hill|2004|pages=67–68}} but notes that the authors of the Synoptic Gospels may have subtly borrowed from Greek literary models.{{sfn|Hill|2004|page=68}} He states that Jesus's healing miracles chiefly differ from those of Asclepius by the fact that Jesus's are attributed to a human being on earth;{{sfn|Hill|2004|page=68}} whereas Asclepius's miracles are performed by a distant god.{{sfn|Hill|2004|page=68}} According to classical historians [[Emma J. Edelstein]] and [[Ludwig Edelstein]], the most obvious difference between Jesus and Asclepius is that Jesus extended his healing to "sinners and publicans";{{sfn|Edelstein|Edelstein|1998|page=134}} whereas Asclepius, as a god, refused to heal those who were ritually impure and confined his healing solely to those who thought pure thoughts.{{sfn|Edelstein|Edelstein|1998|page=134}} Scholars disagree whether the parable of the [[rich man and Lazarus]] recorded in {{bibleverse||Luke|16:19-31|9}} originates with Jesus or if it is a later Christian invention,{{sfn|van Eck|2016|pages=262–265}} but the story bears strong resemblances to various [[Folklore genre|folktales]] told throughout the Near East.{{sfn|van Eck|2016|page=265}}
[[File:Gerard van Honthorst - Adoration of the Shepherds (1622).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.3|''Adoration of the Shepherds'' (1622) by the Dutch painter [[Gerard van Honthorst]]. Modern secular historians regard the birth narrative in the {{bibleref|Luke|1:26–2:52|9}} as a legend invented by early Christians based on Old Testament predecessors.{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pp=85–88}}{{sfn|Farris|2015|page=106}}{{sfn|Litwak|2005|page=75}}]]
It is, however, widely agreed that the portrayal of Jesus in the gospels is deeply influenced by Jewish tradition.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=198–199}}{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pages=88–91, 112–113}} According to [[E. P. Sanders]], a leading scholar on the historical Jesus, the Synoptic Gospels contain many episodes in which Jesus's described actions clearly emulate those of the [[Prophets in Judaism|prophets in the Hebrew Bible]].{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pages=88–91, 112–113}} Sanders states that, in some of these cases, it is impossible to know for certain whether these parallels originate from the historical Jesus himself having deliberately imitated the Hebrew prophets, or from later Christians inventing mythological stories in order to portray Jesus as one of them,{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pages=88–91, 112–113}} but, in many other instances, the parallels are clearly the work of the gospel-writers.{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pages=88–91}} The author of the [[Gospel of Matthew]] in particular intentionally seeks to portray Jesus as a "new [[Moses]]".{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=198–199}}{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pages=90–91}} Matthew's account of [[Massacre of the Innocents|Herod's attempt to kill the infant Jesus]], Jesus's family's [[flight into Egypt]], and their subsequent return to Judaea is a mythical narrative based on the account of [[the Exodus]] in the [[Torah]].{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=198}}{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pages=87–88}}{{sfn|Casey|2010|page=146}} In the Gospel of Matthew, Jesus delivers his [[Sermon on the Mount|first public sermon on a mountain]] in imitation of the giving of the [[Law of Moses]] atop [[Mount Sinai]].{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=199}}{{sfn|Sanders|1993|page=146}} According to New Testament scholars [[Gerd Theissen]] and [[Annette Merz]], the teachings preserved in the sermon are statements that Jesus himself really said on different occasions that were originally recorded without context,{{sfn|Theissen|Merz|1998|pages=17–62}} but the author of the Gospel of Matthew compiled them into an organized lecture and invented context for them in order to fit his portrayal of Jesus as a "new Moses".{{sfn|Theissen|Merz|1998|pages=17–62}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=199}}
According to Sanders, the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth narratives]] in Matthew and Luke are the clearest examples of legends in the Synoptic Gospels.{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pp=85–88}} Both accounts have Jesus born in [[Bethlehem]], in accordance with Jewish salvation history, and both have him growing up in Nazareth,{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pp=85–88}} but they present two completely different and irreconcilable explanations for how that happened.{{sfn|Sanders|1993|pp=85–88}}{{sfn|Casey|2010|pages=146–147}} The accounts of the [[Annunciation]] of Jesus's conception found in {{bibleref|Matthew|1:18–22|9}} and {{bibleref|Luke|1:26–38|9}} are both modeled on the stories of the annunciations of [[Ishmael]], [[Isaac]], and [[Samson]] in the [[Old Testament]].{{sfn|Farris|2015|page=106}}{{sfn|Litwak|2005|page=75}}{{sfn|Casey|2010|pages=149–151}} Matthew quotes from the [[Septuagint]] translation of {{bibleverse||Isaiah|7:14|9}} to support his account of the virgin birth of Jesus.{{sfn|Seidler|2006|page=39}} The Hebrew text of this verse states "Behold, the young woman [''ha‘almāh''] is with child and about to bear a son and she will call him Immanuel."{{sfn|Seidler|2006|page=39}} The Septuagint, however, translates the Hebrew word ''‘almāh'', which literally means "young woman",{{sfn|Seidler|2006|page=39}} as the Greek word παρθένος (''parthenos''), which means "virgin".{{sfn|Seidler|2006|page=39}} Most secular historians therefore generally see the two separate accounts of the virgin birth from the Gospels of Matthew and Luke as independent legendary inventions designed to fulfill the mistranslated passage from Isaiah.{{sfn|Bruner|2004|page=37}}{{sfn|Machen|1987|page=252}}{{sfn|Marchadour|Neuhaus|Martini|2009|pages=67–68}} Sanders clarifies that the birth narratives are "an extreme case" resulting from the authors of the gospels lack of knowledge about Jesus's birth and childhood;{{sfn|Sanders|1993|page=88}} no other part of the gospels relies so heavily on Old Testament parallels.{{sfn|Sanders|1993|page=88}} Sanders also notes that, despite the clearly intentional parallels, the "striking differences" between Jesus and the prophets of the Old Testament are also highly significant{{sfn|Sanders|1993|page=89}} and the gospels' accounts of Jesus's life on the whole do not closely resemble the lives of any of the figures in the Hebrew Bible.{{sfn|Sanders|1993|page=88}}
[[File:Heracles freeing Prometheus, relief from the Temple of Aphrodite at Aphrodisias.jpg|thumb|Greek relief carving from [[Aphrodisias]] showing [[Heracles]] unchaining [[Prometheus]] from the [[Caucasus Mountains]]. [[Martin Hengel]] notes that the only apparent instance from classical literature of a god being crucified is a satirical retelling of the binding of Prometheus from the late second century.{{sfn|Hengel|1977|page=11}}]]
Although Jesus's crucifixion is one of the few events in his life that virtually all scholars of all different backgrounds agree really happened,<ref name=Hertzog1/><ref name="MAPowell168"/><ref name=JDunn339/><ref name="autogenerated145" /><ref name=AmyJill4/> historians of religion have also compared it to Greek and Roman stories in order to gain a better understanding of how non-Christians would have perceived stories of Jesus's crucifixion.{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=12–13}} The German historian of religion [[Martin Hengel]] notes that the Hellenized Syrian satirist [[Lucian|Lucian of Samosata]] ("the [[Voltaire]] of antiquity"), in his comic dialogue ''Prometheus'', written in the second century AD (about two hundred years after Jesus), describes the god [[Prometheus]] being fastened to two rocks in the [[Caucasus Mountains]] using all the terminology of a Roman crucifixion:{{sfn|Hengel|1977|page=11}} he is nailed through the hands in such a manner as to produce "a most serviceable cross" ("ἐπικαιρότατος... ὁ σταυρος").{{sfn|Hengel|1977|page=11}} The gods [[Hermes]] and [[Hephaestus]], who perform the binding, are shown as slaves whose brutal master [[Zeus]] threatens with the same punishment if they weaken.{{sfn|Hengel|1977|page=11}} Unlike the crucifixion of Jesus in the Synoptic Gospels, Lucian's crucifixion of Prometheus is a deliberate, angry mockery of the gods,{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=12–13}} intended to show Zeus as a cruel and capricious tyrant undeserving of praise or adoration.{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=12–13}} This is the only instance from all of classical literature in which a god is apparently crucified{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=12–13}} and the fact that the Greeks and Romans could only conceive of a god being crucified as a form of "malicious parody" demonstrates the kind of horror with which they would have regarded Christian stories of Jesus's crucifixion.{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=12–13}}
American theologian [[Dennis R. MacDonald]] has argued that the Gospel of Mark is, in fact, a Jewish retelling of the ''[[Odyssey]]'', with its ending derived from the ''[[Iliad]]'', that uses Jesus as its central character in the place of [[Odysseus]].{{sfn|MacDonald|pages=1–4}} According to MacDonald, the gospels are primarily intended to show Jesus as superior to Greek heroes{{sfn|MacDonald|pages=1–4}} and, although Jesus himself was a real historical figure, the gospels should be read as works of [[historical fiction]] centered on a real protagonist, not as accurate accounts of Jesus's life.{{sfn|MacDonald|pages=1–4}} MacDonald's thesis that the gospels are modeled on the Homeric Epics has been met with intense skepticism in scholarly circles due to its almost complete reliance on extremely vague and subjective parallels.{{sfn|Sandnes|2005|pages=714–732}}{{sfn|Watts|2013|pages=11–18}}{{sfn|Perkins|2007|pages=23–24}}{{sfn|Meyer|2013|pages=149–150}} Other scholars state that his argument is also undermined by the fact that the Gospel of Mark never directly quotes from either of the Homeric Epics{{sfn|Sandnes|2005|pages=714–732}}{{sfn|Watts|2013|pages=12–13}}{{sfn|Perkins|2007|page=24}} and uses completely dissimilar language.{{sfn|Sandnes|2005|pages=714–732}}{{sfn|Watts|2013|pages=12–13}}{{sfn|Perkins|2007|page=24}} Pheme Perkins also notes that many of the incidents in the Gospel of Mark that MacDonald claims are derived from the ''Odyssey'' have much closer parallels in the Old Testament.{{sfn|Perkins|2007|page=24}} MacDonald's argument, in a misunderstood form, has nonetheless become popular in non-scholarly circles, mostly on the internet, where it is used to support the Christ Myth theory.{{sfn|MacDonald|2009|pages=23–24}} MacDonald himself rejects this interpretation as too drastic.{{sfn|MacDonald|2009|pages=23–24}}
===Gospel of John=== [[File:Dionysos kantharos BM B589.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|Late sixth-century BC [[black-figure]] painting showing [[Dionysus]] extending a ''[[kantharos]]'', a kind of drinking cup. Some scholars have argued that the portrayal of Jesus in the [[Gospel of John]] may have been influenced by Dionysian symbolism.{{sfn|Salier|2004|pages=66–69}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1993|pages=241–242}}{{sfn|Shorroch|2011|pages=57–64}}{{sfn|Orchard|1998|pages=129–132}}{{sfn|Kierspel|2006|pages=202–203}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|pages=131–134}}]]
The [[Gospel of John]], the latest of the four canonical gospels, was influenced by ideas from [[Platonism]].{{sfn|Smalley|2012|pages=47–48}}{{sfn|Porter|2015|pages=102–104}} The "[[Logos]]" described in John's prologue is originally a concept from Greek philosophy,{{sfn|Porter|2015|pages=102–104}} devised by the [[Pre-Socratic philosophy|Pre-Socratic philosopher]] [[Heraclitus]] and adapted to Judaism by the Jewish [[Middle Platonism|Middle Platonist]] [[Philo|Philo of Alexandria]].{{sfn|Porter|2015|pages=102–104}} However, the author of the Gospel of John probably did not borrow the Logos theology from Platonic texts directly;{{sfn|Smalley|2012|pages=47–48}}{{sfn|Porter|2015|pages=102–104}} instead, these sources probably influenced earlier Jewish deuterocanonical texts, which John inherited and expanded his own Logos theology from.{{sfn|Smalley|2012|pages=47–48}}{{sfn|Porter|2015|pages=102–104}} In Platonic terminology, Logos was a universal force that represented the rationality and intelligibility of the world.<ref>Hornblower, Simon, Antony Spawforth, and Esther Eidinow, eds. The Oxford classical dictionary. Oxford University Press, 1996, 882</ref> On the other hand, as adapted into Judaism, Logos becomes a mediating divine figure between God and man and mostly owed influence from [[Wisdom literature]], and by the time it was transmitted into Judaism, seems to have retained the concept of the universality of the Platonic logos. Davies and Finkelstein write "This primeval and universal Wisdom had, at God's command, found itself a home on Mount Zion in Jerusalem. This mediatorial figure, which in its universality can be compared with the Platonic 'world-soul' or the Stoic 'logos', is here exclusively connected with Israel, God's chosen people, and with his sanctuary."<ref>Sturdy, John, Louis Finkelstein, and William David Davies, eds. The Cambridge History of Judaism: The Hellenistic Age. Cambridge University Press, 2007, 223-224</ref>
Scholars have long suspected that the Gospel of John may have also been influenced by symbolism associated with the cult of [[Dionysus]], the Greek god of wine.{{sfn|Salier|2004|pages=66–69}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1993|pages=241–242}}{{sfn|Shorroch|2011|pages=57–64}}{{sfn|Orchard|1998|pages=129–132}}{{sfn|Kierspel|2006|pages=202–203}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|pages=131–134}} The issue of whether the Gospel of John was truly influenced by the cult of Dionysus is hotly disputed,{{sfn|Salier|2004|pages=66–69}} with reputable scholars passionately defending both sides of the argument.{{sfn|Salier|2004|pages=66–69}} Dionysus was one of the best-known Greek deities;{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=67}} he was worshipped throughout most of the [[Greco-Roman world]]{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=67}} and his cult is attested in Palestine, Asia Minor, and Italy.{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=67}} At the same time, other scholars have argued that it is highly implausible that the devout Christian author of the Gospel of John would have deliberately incorporated Dionysian imagery into his account{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=67}} and instead argue that the symbolism of wine in the Gospel of John is much more likely to be based on the many references to wine found throughout the Old Testament.{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=67}} In response to this objection, proponents of Dionysian influence have argued that it is possible that the author of the Gospel of John may have used Dionysian imagery in effort to show Jesus as "superior" to Dionysus.{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=67}}{{sfn|Kierspel|2006|page=202}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=132}}
The first instance of possible Dionysian influence is Jesus's miracle of turning water into wine at the [[Marriage at Cana]] in {{bibleverse||John|2:1-11|9}}.{{sfn|Salier|2004|pages=66–69}}{{sfn|Kierspel|2006|page=202}} The story bears some resemblance to a number of stories that were told about Dionysus.{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=66}} Dionysus's close associations with wine are attested as early as the writings of [[Plato]]{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=66}} and the second-century AD Greek geographer [[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] describes a ritual in which Dionysus was said to fill empty barrels that had been left locked inside a temple overnight with wine.<ref>Pausanias, ''Description of Greece'' 2.26</ref>{{sfn|Salier|2004|pages=67–68}} In the Greek novel ''[[Leucippe and Clitophon]]'' by [[Achilles Tatius]], written in the first or second century AD, a herdsman takes Dionysus into his home and offers him a meal,{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=68}} but can only offer him the same thing to drink as his oxen.{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=68}} Miraculously, Dionysus turns the drink into wine.{{sfn|Salier|2004|page=68}} The account of turning water into wine does not occur in any of the Synoptic Gospels and is only found in the Gospel of John,{{sfn|Shorroch|2011|page=57}} indicating that the author of the fourth gospel may have invented it.{{sfn|Shorroch|2011|page=57}}{{sfn|Kierspel|2006|page=202}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=132}} A second occurrence of possible Dionysian influence is the allegory found in {{bibleverse||John|15:1-17|9}}, in which Jesus declares himself to be the "[[True Vine]]",{{sfn|Shorroch|2011|page=57}} a title reminiscent of Dionysus, who was said to have discovered the first grape vine.{{sfn|Shorroch|2011|page=57}}
[[File:Pompeii - Casa dei Vettii - Pentheus.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.3|First-century AD Roman wall painting from the [[House of the Vettii]] in [[Pompeii]] showing Dionysus's enemy [[Pentheus]] being torn to pieces by the ''[[maenad]]s'', Dionysus's female followers, the climactic scene of [[Euripides]]'s ''[[The Bacchae|Bacchae]]'']]
Mark S. W. Stibbe has argued that the Gospel of John also contains parallels with ''[[The Bacchae]]'', a tragedy written by the Athenian playwright [[Euripides]] that was first performed in 405 BC and involves Dionysus as a central character.{{sfn|Stibbe|1993|page=241}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|pages=134–136}} In both works, the central figure is portrayed as an incarnate deity who arrives in a country where he should be known and worshipped,{{sfn|Stibbe|1993|page=241}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|pages=134–135}} but, because he is disguised as a mortal, the deity is not recognized and is instead persecuted by the ruling party.{{sfn|Stibbe|1993|page=241}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|pages=134–135}} In the Gospel of John, Jesus is portrayed as elusive, intentionally making ambiguous statements to evade capture, much like Dionysus in Euripides's ''Bacchae''.{{sfn|Stibbe|1993|page=241}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=135}} In both works, the deity is supported by a group of female followers.{{sfn|Stibbe|1993|page=241}}{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=135}} Both works end with the violent death of one of the central figures;{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=135}} in John's gospel it is Jesus himself, but in ''The Bacchae'' it is Dionysus's cousin and adversary [[Pentheus]], the king of Thebes.{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=135}}{{refn|group=nb|In the ''Bacchae'', Pentheus is not crucified, but torn apart by the ''[[maenad]]s'', Dionysus's female followers. In a later [[Euhemerism|euhemerized]] retelling of the myth of Pentheus from the third century BC, however, the Greek historian [[Diodorus Siculus]] states that Dionysus crossed the [[Hellespont]] and "defeated the [[Thrace|Thracian]] forces in battle. Lycurgus, whom he took prisoner, he blinded, tortured in every conceivable way and finally crucified."{{sfn|Hengel|1977|page=13}}<ref name="DiodorusSiculus">[[Diodorus Siculus]] ''Universal History'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0540%3Abook%3D3%3Achapter%3D65%3Asection%3D5 3.65.5]</ref> This represents a unique instance in which Dionysus is shown as a god who crucifies his enemies.{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=11–13}}}}
Stibbe emphasizes that two accounts are also radically different,{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}} but states that they share similar themes.{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}} One of the most obvious differences is that, in ''The Bacchae'', Dionysus has come to advocate a philosophy of wine and [[hedonism]];{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}} whereas Jesus in the Gospel of John has come to offer his followers salvation from sin.{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}} Euripides portrays Dionysus as aggressive and violent;{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}} whereas the Gospel of John shows Jesus as peaceful and full of mercy.{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}} Furthermore, ''The Bacchae'' is set within an explicitly polytheistic world,{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}} but the Gospel of John admits the existence of only two gods: Jesus himself and his [[God the Father|Father in Heaven]].{{sfn|Stibbe|1994|page=136}}
===Infancy Gospel of Thomas=== The [[Infancy Gospel of Thomas]] is a short apocryphal gospel, probably written in the second century AD, describing Jesus's childhood.{{sfn|Aasgaard|2010|page=1}} It is unique as the only purported account of Jesus's childhood to survive from early Christian times.{{sfn|Aasgaard|2010|page=1}} It describes a variety of miracles attributed to the young Jesus.{{sfn|Aasgaard|2010|pages=1–2}} It remained continuously in popular use throughout the Middle Ages up until the time of the [[Reformation]].{{sfn|Aasgaard|2010|page=2}} Reidar Aasgaard has argued that the Infancy Gospel may have been partially intended for children{{sfn|Aasgaard|2010|pages=196–198}} and discusses how the stories in the gospel fit the genre of Greco-Roman fairy tales.{{sfn|Aasgaard|2010|pages=196–202}} J. R. C. Cousland argues that the Infancy Gospel may have been originally written for a primarily pagan audience,{{sfn|Cousland|2017|pages=}} noting that the Greeks and Romans told stories about their gods' miraculous doings as children{{sfn|Cousland|2017|pages=122–123}} and that miracle stories were often instrumental in converting pagans to Christianity.{{sfn|Cousland|2017|pages=123–124}}
==Syncretisms in late antiquity== ===Mithraism=== [[File:Mithra sacrifiant le Taureau-005.JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.3|Ancient Roman ''[[tauroctony]]'' dating to the third century AD, depicting Mithras slaying the bull, the most important story of the [[Mithraism|Mithraic Cult]]{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|pages=9–11}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}}{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=12}}]]
Around the same time that Christianity was expanding, the [[Mithraism|cult of the god Mithras]] was also spreading throughout the Roman Empire.{{sfn|Patella|2006|pages=1–2, 9}} Very little is known for certain about the Mithraic cult because it was a "[[Greco-Roman mysteries|Mystery Cult]]", meaning its members were forbidden from disclosing what the cult believed to outsiders.{{sfn|Patella|2006|pages=3–4}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} No Mithraic sacred texts have survived, if any such writings ever existed.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}}{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=2}} Consequently, it is disputed how much influence Christianity and Mithraism may have had on each other.{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=2}} Michael Patella states that the similarities between Christianity and Mithraism are more likely a result of their shared cultural environment rather than direct borrowing from one to the other.{{sfn|Patella|2006|pages=2–4}} Christianity and Mithraism were both of Oriental origin{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=9}} and their practices and respective savior figures were both shaped by the social conditions in the Roman Empire during the time period.{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=2}}
Most of what is known about the legendary life of Mithras comes from archaeological excavation of [[Mithraeum|Mithraea]], underground Mithraic sanctuaries of worship, which were found all across the Roman world.{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=8}}{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|page=6}} Like Jesus, Mithras was seen as a divine savior,{{sfn|Patella|2006|pages=1–9}}{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|page=125}} but, unlike Jesus, Mithras was not believed to have brought his salvation by suffering and dying.{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=8}} Mithras was believed to have been born fully-grown from a rock,{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|pages=35–36}}{{sfn|Clauss|2001|pages=62–66}} a belief which is confirmed by a vast number of surviving sculptures showing him rising from the rock nude except for a [[Phrygian cap]], clutching a sword in his right hand and a torch in his left.{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|pages=35–36}}{{sfn|Clauss|2001|pages=62–66}} In many depictions, the rock is also encircled by a snake.{{sfn|Clauss|2001|page=67}} In Mithraic cults primarily from the Rhine-Danube region, there are also representations of a myth in which Mithras shoots an arrow at a rock face, causing water to gush forth.{{sfn|Clauss|2001|pages=71–72}} This myth is one of the closest parallels between Mithras and Jesus.{{sfn|Clauss|2001|page=72}} Both Christians and Mithraists used water as a symbol for their respective saviors.{{sfn|Clauss|2001|page=72}} In the New Testament, Jesus is referred to as the "[[Water of Life (Christianity)|water of life]]"{{sfn|Clauss|2001|page=72}} and a votive altar to Mithras from [[Ptuj|Poetovio]] proclaims him as the ''fons perennis'' ("the ever-flowing stream").{{sfn|Clauss|2001|page=72}}
In the center of every Mithraeum was a ''[[tauroctony]]'',{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|page=6}}{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=12}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} a painting or sculpture showing Mithras as a young man, usually wearing a cape and Phrygian cap, plunging a knife into the neck or shoulder of a bull as he turns its head towards him, simultaneously turning his own head away.{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=12}}{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|page=11}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} A dog laps up the blood pouring from the bull's wound, from which emerges an ear of corn,{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} as a scorpion stings the bull's [[scrotum]].{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} [[Cautes and Cautopates|Human torchbearers]] stand on either side of the scene, one holding his torch upright and other upside-down.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} A serpent is also present.{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|page=11}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} The exact interpretation of this scene is unclear,{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} but the image certainly depicts a narrative central to Mithraism{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|pages=9–11}}{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=12}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} and the figures in it appear to correspond to the signs of the [[zodiac]].{{sfn|Ulansey|1989|pages=16–20}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}}{{sfn|Patella|2006|page=12}} The closest parallel between Jesus and Mithras is the use of a ritual meal.{{sfn|Clauss|2001|pages=72, 169}} After slaying the bull, Mithras was believed to have shared the bull's meat with the sun-god [[Sol Invictus]], a meal which is shown in Mithraic iconography and which was ritually reenacted by Mithraists as part of their liturgy.{{sfn|Clauss|2001|pages=112–116}} Manfred Clauss, a scholar of the Mithraic cult, speculates that the similarities between Christianity and Mithraism may have made it easier for members of the Mithraic cult to convert to Christianity without having to give up their ritual meal, sun-imagery, candles, incense, or bells,{{sfn|Clauss|2001|pages=171–172}} a trend which might explain why, as late as the sixth century, the Christian Church was still trying to stamp out the ''stulti homines'' who still paid obeisance to the sun every morning on the steps of the church itself.{{sfn|Clauss|2001|page=172}}
{{multiple image | total_width = 300 | footer = | align = left | image1 = MitraRisingfromtherockMNIR.JPG | width1 = 2592 | height1 = 3888 | alt1 = | caption1 = Mithras rising from the rock ([[National Museum of Romanian History]]) | image2 = Mithras petra genetrix Terme.jpg | width2 = 1350 | height2 = 2700 | alt2 = | caption2 = Mithras born from the rock ({{circa|186}} AD; [[Baths of Diocletian]]) }}
A few Christian apologists from the second and third centuries, who had never been members of the Mithraic cult and had never spoken to its members, claimed that the practices of the Mithraic cult were copied off Christianity.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=213}} The second-century Christian apologist [[Justin Martyr]] writes in his ''[[First Apology of Justin Martyr|First Apology]]'', after describing the Christian [[Eucharist]], that "...the wicked devils have imitated [this] in the mysteries of Mithras, commanding the same thing to be done. For, that bread and a cup of water are placed with certain incantations in the mystic rites of one who is being initiated, you either know or can learn."<ref>''First Apology of Justin Martyr'', [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf01.viii.ii.lxvi.html Chapter 66]</ref> The later apologist [[Tertullian]] writes in his ''De praescriptione haereticorum'':
<blockquote>The devil (is the inspirer of the heretics) whose work it is to pervert the truth, who with idolatrous mysteries endeavours to imitate the realities of the divine sacraments. Some he himself sprinkles as though in token of faith and loyalty; he promises forgiveness of sins through baptism; and if my memory does not fail me marks his own soldiers with the sign of Mithra on their foreheads, commemorates an offering of bread, introduces a mock resurrection, and with the sword opens the way to the crown. Moreover has he not forbidden a second marriage to the supreme priest? He maintains also his virgins and his celibates.<ref>Tertullian, ''De praescriptione haereticorum'' [http://www.tertullian.org/fathers2/ANF-03/anf03-24.htm#P3664_1234278 4-.3-4]</ref></blockquote>
According to Ehrman, these writers were ideologically motivated to portray Christianity and Mithraism as similar because they wanted to persuade pagan officials that Christianity was not so different from other religious traditions, so that these officials would realize that there was no reason to single Christians out for persecution.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=213–214}} These apologists therefore intentionally exaggerated similarities between Christianity and Mithraism to support their arguments.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=213–214}} Scholars are generally wary of trusting anything these sources have to say about the Mithraic cult's alleged practices.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=214}}
===Iconography=== {{main|Depiction of Jesus}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | width = <!-- Image 1 --> | image1 = Rom, Domitilla-Katakomben, Der gute Hirte.jpg | width1 = 200 | alt1 = | caption1 = Christian statue of Jesus as the "[[Good Shepherd]]" ({{circa}} 300-350) from the [[Catacombs of Rome#Catacombs of Domitilla|Catacombs of Domitilla]], [[Rome]] <!-- Image 2 --> | image2 = Hermes crioforo.jpg | width2 = 250 | alt2 = | caption2 = Late Roman copy of a fifth-century BC Greek statue showing [[Hermes]], the god of travelers, carrying a ram over his shoulders in his role as [[Kriophoros]] (the "Ram-Bearer") }} [[File:Dionysus_Crucifixion.png|thumb|[[Hematite]] gem inscribed with the image of a crucified man identified as ΟΡΦΕΩΣ ΒΑΚΧΙΚΟΣ (''Orpheos Bacchikos'').{{sfn|Carotta|Eickenberg|2009|page=4}}{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=13 and 22}} This gem may represent an unusual instance of pagans adapting Christian iconography rather than vice versa.{{sfn|Carotta|Eickenberg|2009|page=4}}]]
In [[late antiquity]], [[Early Christianity|early Christians]] frequently adapted pagan iconography to suit Christian purposes.{{sfn|Taylor|1993|pages=96–97}}{{sfn|Link|1995|pages=43–45}} This does not in any way indicate that Christianity itself was derived from paganism,{{sfn|Taylor|1993|pages=96–97}} only that early Christians made use of the pre-existing symbols that were readily available in their society.{{sfn|Taylor|1993|pages=96–97}} Sometimes Christians deliberately used pagan iconography in conscious effort to show Jesus as superior to the pagan gods.{{sfn|Taylor|2018|pages=119–121}} In classical iconography, the god [[Hermes]] was sometimes shown as a ''[[kriophoros]]'', a handsome, beardless youth bearing a ram or sheep over his shoulders.{{sfn|Jensen|2000|page=37}} In late antiquity, this image developed a generic association with philanthropy.{{sfn|Jensen|2000|page=37}} Early Christians adapted images of this kind as representations of Jesus in his role of as the "[[Good Shepherd]]".{{sfn|Jensen|2000|pages=37–38}}
Early Christians also identified Jesus with the Greek hero [[Orpheus]],{{sfn|Friedman|2000|pages=38–61}} who was said to have tamed wild beasts with the music of his lyre.{{sfn|Friedman|2000|pages=55–57}} The [[church fathers|Church Father]] [[Clement of Alexandria]] writes that Orpheus and Jesus are similar in that they have both been subject to admiration on account of their "songs",{{sfn|Friedman|2000|page=56}} but insists that Orpheus misused his gift of eloquence by persuading people to worship idols and "tie themselves to temporal things";{{sfn|Friedman|2000|page=56}} whereas Jesus, the singer of the "New Song" brings peace to men and frees them from the bonds of the flesh.{{sfn|Friedman|2000|page=56}} The later Christian historian [[Eusebius]], drawing on Clement, also compares Orpheus to Jesus for having both brought peace to men.{{sfn|Friedman|2000|pages=56–57}} One unusual possible instance of identification between Jesus and Orpheus is a [[hematite]] gem inscribed with the image of a crucified man identified as ΟΡΦΕΩΣ ΒΑΚΧΙΚΟΣ (''Orpheos Bacchikos'').{{sfn|Carotta|Eickenberg|2009|page=4}}{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=13 and 22}} The gem has long been suspected to be a forgery created in the late seventeenth or early eighteenth century,{{sfn|Carotta|Eickenberg|2009|pages=1–3}}{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=13 and 22}} but, if authentic, it may date to the late second or early third century AD.{{sfn|Carotta|Eickenberg|2009|page=4}}{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=13 and 22}} If authentic, the gem would represent a remarkable instance of pagans adopting Christian iconography, rather than ''vice versa'' as is generally more common.{{sfn|Carotta|Eickenberg|2009|page=4}} The gem was formerly housed at the [[Altes Museum]] in [[Berlin]], but was lost or destroyed during [[World War II]].{{sfn|Carotta|Eickenberg|2009|page=1}}{{sfn|Hengel|1977|pages=13 and 22}}
Early Christians found it hard to criticize Asclepius because, while their usual tactics were to denounce the absurdity of believing in gods who were merely personifications of nature and to accuse pagan gods of being immoral,{{sfn|Edelstein|Edelstein|1998|page=135}} neither of these could be applied to Asclepius, who was never portrayed as a personification of nature and whose stories were inscrutably moral.{{sfn|Edelstein|Edelstein|1998|page=135}} The early Christian apologist [[Justin Martyr]] argued that believing in Jesus's divinity should not be hard for pagans, since it was no different from believing in the divinity of Asclepius.{{sfn|Edelstein|Edelstein|1998|page=135}} Eventually, Christians adapted much of the iconography of Asclepius to suit the miracles of Jesus.{{sfn|Jefferson|2014|pages=6–7}}{{sfn|Ferngren|2009|page=41}} Images of Jesus as a healer replaced images of Asclepius and [[Hippocrates]] as the ideal physician.{{sfn|Ferngren|2009|page=41}} Jesus, who was originally shown as clean-shaven, may have first been shown as bearded as a result of this syncretism with Asclepius,{{sfn|Ogden|2013|page=420}}{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=82}} as well as other bearded deities such as [[Zeus]] and [[Serapis]].{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=82}} A second-century AD head of Asclepius was discovered underneath a fourth-century AD Christian church in [[Jerash|Gerasa, Jordan]].{{sfn|Ogden|2013|page=420}}
In some depictions from late antiquity, Jesus was shown with the [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]] of the sun god [[Sol Invictus]].{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=122}} Images of "[[Christ in Majesty]]" seated upon a throne were inspired by classical depictions of Zeus and other chief deities.{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=82}} By the fourth century AD, the recognizable image of Jesus as long-haired, bearded, and clad in long, baggy-sleeved clothing had fully emerged.{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=82}} This widespread adaptation of pagan iconography to suit Jesus did not sit well with many Christians.{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=118}} A fragment of a lost work by Theodor Lector preserves a miracle story dated to around 465 AD in which the bishop [[Gennadius of Constantinople]] was said to have healed an artist who had lost all strength in his hand after painting an image of Christ showing him with long, curly hair, parted in the same manner as traditional representations of Zeus.{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=118}}
Christians also may have adapted the iconography of the Egyptian goddess [[Isis]] nursing her son [[Horus]] and applied it to the [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Virgin Mary]] nursing her son Jesus.{{sfn|Reid|2002|page=24}}{{sfn|Johnson|Johnson|2007|page=79}} Some Christians also may have conflated stories about the Egyptian god [[Osiris]] with the resurrection of Jesus.{{sfn|Reid|2002|page=24}}{{sfn|Johnson|Johnson|2007|page=79}} The title of ''kosmokrateros'' ("Ruler of the Cosmos"), which was eventually applied to Jesus, had previously been borne by Serapis.{{sfn|Taylor|2018|page=121}} The [[Church Fathers|Church Father]] [[Jerome]] records in a letter dated to the year 395 AD that "Bethlehem... belonging now to us... was overshadowed by a grove of [[Dumuzid|Tammuz]], that is to say, [[Adonis]], and in the cave where once the infant Christ cried, the lover of [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] was lamented."{{sfn|Taylor|1993|page=96}} This same cave later became the site of the [[Church of the Nativity]].{{sfn|Taylor|1993|page=96}} The church historian [[Eusebius]], however, does not mention pagans having ever worshipped in the cave,{{sfn|Taylor|1993|page=96}} nor do any other early Christian writers.{{sfn|Taylor|1993|page=96}} Peter Welten has argued that the cave was never dedicated to Tammuz{{sfn|Taylor|1993|page=96}} and that Jerome misinterpreted Christian mourning over the [[Massacre of the Innocents]] as a pagan ritual over Tammuz's death.{{sfn|Taylor|1993|page=96}} Joan E. Taylor has countered this argument by arguing that Jerome, as an educated man, could not have been so naïve as to mistake Christian mourning over the Massacre of the Innocents as a pagan ritual for Tammuz.{{sfn|Taylor|1993|pages=96–97}} During the sixth century AD, some Christians in the Middle East borrowed elements from poems of Tammuz's wife [[Inanna|Ishtar]] mourning over her husband's death into their own retellings of the [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Virgin Mary]] mourning over the death of her son Jesus.{{sfn|Warner|2016|pages=210–212}}{{sfn|Baring|Cashford|1991}} The Syrian writers [[Jacob of Serugh]] and [[Romanos the Melodist]] both wrote laments in which the Virgin Mary describes her compassion for her son at the foot of the cross in deeply personal terms closely resembling Ishtar's laments over the death of Tammuz.{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=212}}
<gallery mode=packed heights="200px"> File:Le Jupiter Olympien ou l'art de la sculpture antique.jpg|Reconstruction by [[Quatremère de Quincy]] (1815) of [[Phidias]]'s [[Statue of Zeus at Olympia]], based on ancient descriptions and surviving copies File:Lucca.San Frediana02.JPG|Thirteenth-century Byzantine mosaic of [[Christ in Majesty]] from the [[Basilica of San Frediano]] File:Disc Sol BM GR1899.12-1.2.jpg|Third-century AD Roman imperial [[repoussé]] [[silver]] disc found at [[Pessinus]] showing [[Sol Invictus]] with a [[parhelion]] File:Christus Ravenna Mosaic.jpg|Byzantine mosaic of Jesus with his head surrounded by a halo ({{circa}} 526 AD) File:Figure-6-Fresco-of-Isis-lactans-at-Karanis-fourth-century-CE-Karanis-Tran-Tam-Tinh.png|thumb|right|upright|Egyptian fresco from the fourth century AD showing ''Isis Lactans'' holding [[Harpocrates]] File:Mary & Child Icon Sinai 6th century.jpg|Sixth-century AD [[icon]] of the enthroned ''[[Virgin and Child]]'' with saints and angels, and the [[Hand of God (art)|Hand of God]] above, from [[Saint Catherine's Monastery]], possibly the earliest iconic image of the subject to survive </gallery>
===Birthdate=== {{main|Christmas}} The Bible never states when Jesus was born,{{sfn|Aldrete|Aldrete|2012|page=82}}{{sfn|John|2001|page=112}}{{sfn|Struthers|2012|pages=17–21}} but, by late antiquity, Christians had begun celebrating his birth on 25 December.{{sfn|John|2001|page=112}} In 274 AD, the Roman emperor [[Aurelian]] had declared 25 December the birthdate of [[Sol Invictus]], a sun god of Syrian origin whose cult had been vigorously promoted by the earlier emperor [[Elagabalus]].{{sfn|Aldrete|Aldrete|2012|pages=82–83}}{{sfn|Struthers|2012|pages=17–21}} Christians may have thought that they could attract more converts to Christianity by allowing them to continue to celebrate on the same day.{{sfn|Struthers|2012|pages=17–21}} 25 December also falls around the same time as the Roman festival of [[Saturnalia]], which was much older and more widely celebrated.{{sfn|Aldrete|Aldrete|2012|pages=83–84}}{{sfn|John|2001|page=112}} Many of the customs originally associated with Saturnalia eventually became associated with Christmas.{{sfn|Aldrete|Aldrete|2012|pages=83–84}}{{sfn|John|2001|page=112}} Early Christians may have also been influenced by the idea that Jesus had died on the anniversary of his conception;{{sfn|Struthers|2012|pages=17–21}} because Jesus died during Passover and, in the third century AD, Passover was celebrated on 25 March,{{sfn|Struthers|2012|pages=17–21}} they may have assumed that Jesus's birthday must have come nine months later, on 25 December.{{sfn|Struthers|2012|pages=17–21}}
==General comparisons== Aspects of Jesus's life as recorded in the gospels bear some similarities to various other figures, both historical and mythological.{{sfn|Ehrman|2010|pages=207–218}}{{sfn|Casey|2014|pages=203–204}} Proponents of the Christ Myth theory frequently exaggerate these similarities as part of their efforts to claim that Jesus never existed as a historical figure.{{sfn|Ehrman|2010|pages=207–218}}{{sfn|Casey|2014|pages=203–204}} [[Maurice Casey]], the late Emeritus Professor of New Testament Languages and Literature at the [[University of Nottingham]], writes that these parallels do not in any way indicate that Jesus was invented based on pagan "divine men",{{sfn|Casey|2014|page=203}} but rather that he was simply not as perfectly unique as many [[Evangelicalism|evangelical Christians]] frequently claim he was.{{sfn|Casey|2014|page=203}}
===Miraculous birth=== [[File:Birth Erikhthonios Staatliche Antikensammlungen 2413 n2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Attica|Attic]] red-figure ''[[stamnos]]'' ({{circa}} 470–460 BC), depicting the birth of [[Erichthonius of Athens|Erichthonius]] from [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]], an Athenian story which bears some similarities to the Christian account of the virgin birth of Jesus.{{sfn|Deacy|2008|page=82}}]] {{main|Miraculous birth}} Classical mythology is filled with stories of miraculous births of various kinds,{{sfn|Warner|2016|pages=36–37}}{{sfn|Litwa|2014|pages=62–64}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=214–215}}{{sfn|Casey|2010|pages=147–151}} but, in most cases of divine offspring from classical mythology, the father is a god who engages in literal sexual intercourse with the mother, a mortal woman,{{sfn|Litwa|2014|pages=38, 64–66}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=214}} causing her to give birth to a son who is literally half god and half man.{{sfn|Litwa|2014|pages=64–66}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=214}} A possible pagan precursor to the Christian story of the virgin birth of Jesus is an Athenian legend recounted by the mythographer [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Pseudo-Apollodorus]].{{sfn|Deacy|2008|page=82}}{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=281}} According to this account, [[Hephaestus]], the god of blacksmiths, once attempted to rape Athena, the virgin goddess of wisdom, but she pushed him away, causing him to [[ejaculate]] on her thigh.{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}}{{sfn|Deacy|2008|page=82}}{{snf|Burkert|1985|page=143}} Athena wiped the [[semen]] off using a tuft of [[wool]],{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}}{{sfn|Deacy|2008|page=82}}{{snf|Burkert|1985|page=143}} which she tossed into the dust,{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}}{{sfn|Deacy|2008|page=82}}{{snf|Burkert|1985|page=143}} impregnating [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]] and causing her to give birth to [[Erichthonius of Athens|Erichthonius]],{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}}{{sfn|Deacy|2008|page=82}}{{snf|Burkert|1985|page=143}} whom Athena adopted as her own child.{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}}{{sfn|Deacy|2008|pages=82–83}} Thus, Athena was able to produce a "son" without her losing her virginity.{{sfn|Deacy|2008|pages=82–83}} The Roman mythographer [[Hyginus]]{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=281}} records a similar story in which Hephaestus demanded Zeus to let him marry Athena since he was the one who had smashed open Zeus's skull, allowing Athena to be born.{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}} Zeus agreed to this and Hephaestus and Athena were married,{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}} but, when Hephaestus was about to consummate the union, Athena vanished from the bridal bed, causing him to ejaculate on the floor, thus impregnating Gaia with Erichthonius.{{snf|Kerényi|1951|page=123}}
[[File:Danae gold shower Louvre CA925.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Ancient [[Boeotia]]n [[bell-krater]] showing Zeus impregnating [[Danaë]] in the form of a shower of gold ({{circa}} 450-425 BC), a story which has been compared to the Christian account of the virgin birth of Jesus{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=37}}{{sfn|Litwa|2014|page=42}}{{sfn|Dundes|1980|page=225}}]]
Another comparable story from Greek mythology describes the conception of the hero [[Perseus]].{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=37}}{{sfn|Litwa|2014|page=42}}{{sfn|Dundes|1980|page=225}} According to the myth, Zeus came to Perseus's mother [[Danaë]] in the form of a shower of gold and impregnated her.{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=37}}{{sfn|Machen|1987|page=335}}{{sfn|Dundes|1980|page=225}} Although no surviving Greek text ever describes this as a "virgin birth",{{sfn|Machen|1987|page=335}} the early Christian apologist [[Justin Martyr]] has his Jewish speaker Trypho refer to it as such in his ''[[Dialogue with Trypho]]''.{{sfn|Machen|1987|page=335}}{{sfn|Dundes|1980|page=225}}{{sfn|Warner|2016|pages=36–37}} Scholars have also compared the story of the virgin birth to the complex narratives revolving around the birth of Dionysus.{{sfn|Litwa|2014|page=38}}{{sfn|Warner|2016|pages=35–36}} In most versions of the conception of Dionysus, Zeus was said to have come to the mortal woman [[Semele]] disguised as a mortal and had sex with her.{{sfn|Kerényi|1951|page=257}} Zeus's wife [[Hera]] disguised herself as Semele's nurse and persuaded her to ask Zeus to show her his true, divine form.{{sfn|Kerényi|1951|page=257}} Zeus eventually agreed, but, upon revealing his divine form, Semele was instantly incinerated by his lightning.{{sfn|Kerényi|1951|page=257}} Zeus rescued the unborn infant Dionysus and sewed him inside his own thigh, giving birth to him himself when it was time.{{sfn|Kerényi|1951|pages=257–258}} In an alternative version of the story told by the Roman mythographer [[Gaius Julius Hyginus|Hyginus]], Dionysus was actually the son of Zeus and [[Persephone]],{{sfn|Kerényi|1951|pages=252–257}} who was torn apart by the [[Titan (mythology)|Titans]].{{sfn|Kerényi|1951|pages=252–257}} Zeus rescued Dionysus's heart, ground it up, and mixed it into a potion, which he gave to Semele to drink, causing her to become pregnant with the infant who had been killed.{{sfn|Kerényi|1951|pages=256–257}}
According to M. David Litwa, the authors of the Gospels of Matthew and Luke consciously attempt to avoid portraying Jesus's conception as anything resembling pagan accounts of divine parentage;{{sfn|Litwa|2014|page=64}} the author of the Gospel of Luke tells a similar story about the conception of John the Baptist in effort to emphasize the Jewish character of Jesus's birth.{{sfn|Litwa|2014|page=64}} Nonetheless, Litwe argues that the accounts are unconsciously influenced by pagan stories of divine men, despite their authors' efforts to avert this.{{sfn|Litwa|2014|pages=40–43, 64–66}} Other stories of virgin births similar to Jesus's are referenced by later Christian writers.{{sfn|Warner|2016|pages=37–38}} The third-century AD Christian theologian [[Origen]] retells a legend that [[Plato]]'s mother [[Perictione]] had virginally conceived him after the god Apollo had appeared to her husband [[Ariston of Athens|Ariston]] and told him not to consummate his marriage with his wife,{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=37}}{{sfn|Litwa|2014|page=66}}{{sfn|Cooper|2001|page=81}} a scene closely paralleling the account of the Annunciation to Joseph from the Gospel of Matthew.{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=37}} Origen interpreted this story and others like it as prefiguring the reality made manifest by Jesus's virginal conception.{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=37}}{{sfn|Litwa|2014|pages=65–66}} In the fourth century, the bishop [[Epiphanius of Salamis]] protested that, in Alexandria, at the temple of Kore-Persephone, the pagans enacted a "hideous mockery" of the Christian Epiphany in which they claimed that "Today at this hour Kore, that is the virgin, has given birth to [[Aion (deity)|Aion]]."{{sfn|Warner|2016|page=37}}
===Archetypal folkloric hero=== {{main|Rank-Raglan mythotype|Hero}} Folklorist [[Alan Dundes]] has argued that Jesus fits all but five of the twenty-two narrative patterns in the [[Rank-Raglan mythotype]],{{sfn|Dundes|1980|pages=230–236}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=31}} and therefore more closely matches the archetype than many of the heroes traditionally cited to support it, such as [[Jason]], [[Bellerophon]], [[Pelops]], [[Asclepius]], [[Joseph (Genesis)|Joseph]], [[Elijah]], and [[Sigurd|Siegfried]].{{sfn|Dundes|1980|page=235}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=31}} Dundes sees Jesus as a historical "miracle-worker" or "religious teacher", stories of whose life were told and retold through oral tradition so many times that they became [[legend]].{{sfn|Dundes|1980|pages=224–225, 325}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=314}} Dundes states that analyzing Jesus in the context of folklore helps explain some of the anomalies of the gospels, such as the fact that none of them give any information about Jesus’s childhood and adolescence,{{sfn|Dundes|1980|page=236}} which Dundes explains by the fact that this is "precisely the case for almost all heroes of tradition".{{sfn|Dundes|1980|page=236}} Other scholars have strongly criticized Dundes's application of the Rank-Raglan mythotype to Jesus,{{sfn|Wills|2005|page=228}}{{sfn|Blomart|2004|page=96}} pointing out that Dundes draws the narrative patterns from different texts written centuries apart, without taking care to differentiate between them.{{sfn|Wills|2005|page=228}}{{sfn|Blomart|2004|page=96}} Dundes's application has also been criticized due to the Rank-Raglan mythotype's artificial nature and its lack of specificity to Hellenistic culture.{{sfn|Blomart|2004|page=96}} Nonetheless, Lawrence M. Wills states that the "hero paradigm ''in some form'' does apply to the earliest lives of Jesus", albeit not to the extreme extent that Dundes has argued.{{sfn|Wills|2005|page=228}}
===Dying-and-rising god archetype=== [[File:JamesGeorgeFrazer.jpg|thumb|Photograph of [[James George Frazer|Sir James George Frazer]], the [[Anthropology|anthropologist]] who is most directly responsible for promoting the concept of a "dying and rising god" archetype{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=222–223}}{{sfn|Barstad|1984|page=149}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=142–143}}]] {{main|Dying-and-rising deity}} The late nineteenth-century Scottish [[Anthropology|anthropologist]] [[James George Frazer|Sir James George Frazer]] wrote extensively about the existence of a "dying-and rising god" archetype in his monumental study of comparative religion ''[[The Golden Bough]]'' (the first edition of which was published in 1890){{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=222–223}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=375}} as well as in later works.{{sfn|Barstad|1984|pages=149–150}} Frazer's main intention was to prove that all religions were fundamentally the same{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=222}} and that all the essential features of Christianity could be found in earlier religions.{{sfn|Barstad|1984|page=150}} Although Frazer himself did not explicitly claim that Jesus was a "dying-and-rising god" of the supposedly typical Near Eastern variety, he strongly implied it.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=223}} Frazer's claims became widely influential in late-nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century scholarship of religion,{{sfn|Barstad|1984|page=149}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=142–143}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=222–223}} but are now mostly rejected modern scholars.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=223}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=142–143}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|pages=374–375}}
The main examples of "dying-and-rising gods" discussed by Frazer were the Mesopotamian god [[Dumuzid]]/Tammuz, his Greek equivalent [[Adonis]], the Phrygian god [[Attis]], and the Egyptian god [[Osiris]].{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=222–223}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=375}}{{sfn|Barstad|1984|pages=149–150}} Dumuzid/Tammuz was a god of [[Sumer]]ian origin associated with vegetation and fertility who eventually came to be worshipped across the Near East.{{sfn|Ackerman|2006|page=116}} Dumuzid was associated with springtime agricultural fertility{{sfn|Ackerman|2006|page=116}}{{sfn|Jacobsen|2008|pages=83–84}} and, when the crops withered during the hot summer months, women would mourn over his death.{{sfn|Ackerman|2006|page=116}}{{sfn|Jacobsen|2008|pages=74–87}}{{sfn|Black|Green|1992|page=73}} Tammuz's categorization as a "dying-and-rising god" was based on the abbreviated Akkadian redaction of ''Inanna's Descent into the Underworld'', which was missing the ending.{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=144}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=379}} Since numerous lamentations over the death of Dumuzid had already been translated, scholars filled in the missing ending by assuming that the reason for Ishtar's descent was because she was going to resurrect Dumuzid and that the text could therefore be assumed to end with Tammuz's resurrection.{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=144}}
Then, in the middle of the twentieth century, the complete, unabridged, original Sumerian text of ''Inanna's Descent'' was finally translated,{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=144}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=379}} revealing that, instead of ending with Dumuzid's resurrection as had long been assumed, the text actually ended with Dumuzid's ''death''.{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=144}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=379}} The discovery of the ''Return of Dumuzid'' in 1963 briefly revived hopes that Dumuzid might once again be able to be categorized as a "dying-and-rising god",{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=144}} but the text ultimately proved disappointing in this regard because it does not describe a triumph over death (as would be necessary for a true Frazerian "resurrection myth"){{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=144}}{{sfn|Smith|1987|pages=521–527}} and instead does precisely the opposite and affirms the "inalterable power of the realm of the dead" by the fact that Dumuzid can only leave the Underworld when his sister takes his place.{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=144}}{{sfn|Smith|1987|pages=521–527}}
Frazer and others also saw Tammuz's Greek equivalent Adonis as a "dying-and-rising god",{{sfn|Barstad|1984|page=149}}{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|pages=222–223}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=140–142}} despite the fact that he is never described as rising from the dead in any extant Greco-Roman writings{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=143}} and the only possible allusions to his supposed resurrection come from late, highly ambiguous statements made by Christian authors.{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=143}}{{refn|group=nb|[[Origen]] discusses Adonis, (whom he associates with Tammuz), in his ''Selecta in Ezechielem'' ( “Comments on Ezekiel”), noting that "they say that for a long time certain rites of initiation are conducted: first, that they weep for him, since he has died; second, that they rejoice for him because he has risen from the dead (''apo nekrôn anastanti'')" (cf. J.-P. Migne, ''Patrologiae Cursus Completus: Series Graeca'', '''13:800''').}} Attis is never described as being resurrected either;{{sfn|Smith|1987|page=524}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=143}} although many myths surround his death, none of them ever claim that he was resurrected.{{sfn|Smith|1987|page=524}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=143}} Osiris was never truly resurrected either;{{sfn|Smith|1987|pages=521–527}}{{sfn|Assmann|2001|pages=129–130}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=143–144}} in Egyptian myth, Osiris's brother [[Set (deity)|Set]] was said to have murdered him, chopped his body into pieces, and scattered them across the land.{{sfn|Pinch|2004|pages=80–81}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=143–144}} Osiris's devoted wife [[Isis]] collected his dismembered limbs and reassembled them,{{sfn|Pinch|2004|pages=80–81}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=143–144}} allowing her to revive Osiris in the [[Duat]], the Egyptian afterlife, where he became the king of the dead.{{sfn|Pinch|2004|pages=80–81}}{{sfn|Assmann|2001|pages=129–130}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=143–144}}
In the late twentieth century, scholars began to severely criticize the designation of "dying-and-rising god" altogether.{{sfn|Barstad|1984|pages=149–150}}{{sfn|Smith|1987|pages=521–527}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=374}} In 1987, [[Jonathan Z. Smith]] concluded in [[Mircea Eliade]]'s ''Encyclopedia of Religion'' that "The category of dying and rising gods, once a major topic of scholarly investigation, must now be understood to have been largely a misnomer based on imaginative reconstructions and exceedingly late or highly ambiguous texts."{{sfn|Smith|1987|pages=521–527}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|page=143}} He further argued that the deities previously referred to as "dying-and-rising" would be better termed separately as "dying gods" and "disappearing gods",{{sfn|Smith|1987|pages=521–527}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=374}} asserting that before Christianity, the two categories were distinct and gods who "died" did not return, and those who returned never truly "died".{{sfn|Smith|1987|pages=521–527}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|page=374}} By the end of the twentieth century, most scholars had come to agree that the notion of a "dying-and-rising god" was an invention{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=223}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=142–143}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|pages=374–375}} and that the term was not a useful scholarly designation.{{sfn|Ehrman|2012|page=223}}{{sfn|Eddy|Boyd|2007|pages=142–143}}{{sfn|Mettinger|2004|pages=374–375}}
